quotations.title: Comic Book Quotations
quotations.description: Quotations from various comic book titles.

quotation.p: You're a good guy, Doc. You're sensitive and caring and compassionate. And if I could, I'd spew in your face.
quotation.source: Cliff Steele in DOOM PATROL #19

quotation.p: "Hello, Kay. Isn't it a bit wet to be painting?"
"Kay's down in the underground, where there's no rain. You're talking to the hangman's beautiful daughter."
quotation.source: Magnus and Kay Challis ("Crazy Jane") in DOOM PATROL #19.

quotation.p: I've tried to be like them, I really have. But what happens when you just can't be strong anymore? What happens if you're weak? My painting's ruined. Everything's gone wrong.
quotation.source: Crazy Jane in DOOM PATROL #19

quotation.p: Guy was a human torch, you know? Literally. His hair... everything... but he kept on walking. Real slow, like in a bad dream. Before he died, he said something weird. I... I got it written down right here. "...scissormen... The scissormen!"
quotation.source: A stunned cop in DOOM PATROL #19

quotation.p: It begins to rain fish. Mackerel. Herring. Sea bass. Pike. Sturgeon. Tench. Plaice. Salmon. From a clear sky. Trout. No cod.
quotation.source: Father McGarry's last sight, in DOOM PATROL #20.

quotation.p: "Rain Brain says your voice is like an old black telephone and Black Annis told me to tell you that you're the first man she hasn't wanted to castrate."
"Tell her she'd be too late anyway."
quotation.source: Crazy Jane and Cliff Steele in DOOM PATROL #20.

quotation.p: "Thirdly be grimmer as fond brevities."
"Eider with alders."
"And erethism safer."
quotation.source: Three Scissormen introduce themselves in DOOM PATROL #20

quotation.p: In Rome, in Leningrad, in Darwin. "The door flew open, in he ran, the great, long, red-legged scissorman."
quotation.source: From DOOM PATROL #20

quotation.p: I couldn't think of one clever way to stop this guy, so I just trusted to mindless violence.
quotation.source: Cliff Steele in DOOM PATROL #21

quotation.p: "Jane? Jane, are you... Oh my God."
"There is no God. I killed him."
quotation.source: Cliff Steele meets Black Annis in DOOM PATROL #21.

quotation.p: All I want is the answer to one simple question before I run screaming back to the bughouse. Is this real or isn't it?
quotation.source: Cliff Steele in DOOM PATROL #21

quotation.p: "It might help to consider the Zen koan, 'First there is a mountain, then there is no mountain, then there is.'"
"Sure. That's really helped to clear things up."
quotation.source: Niles Caulder and Cliff Steele in DOOM PATROL #21

quotation.p: Here the skull of a consumptive child becomes part of a great machine for calculating the motions of the stars. Here, a yellow bird frets within the ribcage of an unjust man.
quotation.source: Welcome to Orqwith, in DOOM PATROL #22

quotation.p: You know, all of a sudden I can't think of anything even remotely funny to say.
quotation.source: Cliff Steele sees Orqwith, in DOOM PATROL #22

quotation.p: Sorry about the writing. Robot fingers, you know?
quotation.source: Cliff Steele in DOOM PATROL #23

quotation.p: "You shot your imaginary friends? With what?"
"An imaginary gun! What else?"
quotation.source: Josh and Dorothy in DOOM PATROL #25

quotation.p: I wish I were an angry shoe, a bodiless balloon. Cut off my covenant with God the pain of orthopedic glue.
quotation.source: Darling-Come-Home's song in DOOM PATROL #25

quotation.p: "Shouldn't we put Cliff's brain back into the body?"
"Later, Joshua. I refuse to perform a delicate operation without chocolate."
quotation.source: Josh and Niles Caulder, in DOOM PATROL #34

quotation.p: "Where is my gum? I must try to look as normal as possible."
"I believe you stuck it onto the side of my head."
quotation.source: Monsieur Mallah and the Brain, in DOOM PATROL #34

quotation.p: Chess! I'm tormented by thoughts of strip chess. Pure mind just isn't enough, Mallah. I long for a body.
quotation.source: The Brain, in DOOM PATROL #34

quotation.p: Instead, you and I became the cornerstones of the Brotherhood of Evil! An empire of crime such as I'd dreamed of back in the old school, when the other children used to laugh at me because I was a brain in a tank.
quotation.source: The Brain, in DOOM PATROL #34

quotation.p: I don't think. I just act. You brains are the ones who do all the thinking. You ruin it for us bodies.
quotation.source: Cliff's body, in DOOM PATROL #34

quotation.p: Kiss me, Mallah! But first... please.. take that gum out of your mouth.
quotation.source: The Brain, in DOOM PATROL #34

quotation.p: Oh, Venice, Venice, what have you allowed yourself to become? Crushed by the weight of your own past, stinking slowly into the waves. They've taken away your function, removed you from the present and from the future, and turned you into a drug mainlined into the veins of history junkies.
quotation.source: ??? in DOOM PATROL #50

quotation.p: I'm warning you--I have a boiled egg and I know how to use it!
quotation.source: ??? in DOOM PATROL #50

quotation.p: Now. Take this street to New Mexico.
quotation.source: ??? in DOOM PATROL #50

quotation.p: The Living Guru! Hip-hop bishop of beat! The cool, gone Daddio of the Deva Dimensions!
quotation.source: Grant Morrison goes completely insane in DOOM PATROL #53

quotation.p: You could say it all started in Arizona. Twenty-five years ago. On a farm.
quotation.source: The narrator, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: It was an ordinary sort of farm in Arizona. The kind of place where you'd have sexual relations with your parents and end up shooting someone.
quotation.source: The narrator, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: The well was like an old man who'd lost the desire to get dressed in the mornings. The well would sit around all day in its pajamas waiting for something to happen... Twenty-five years ago something did happen.
quotation.source: The narrator, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: On Tuesdays he also wears the blue socks and the grey underwear and counts his bath towels. He has twenty-five bath towels. But how could anyone survive with less?
quotation.source: The narrator introduces us to Michael Smith, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: Michael is a tree ape who lost most of his hairs and now has nightmares about black horses and cancer. Sometimes he feels like a rumor drifting through a world of hard facts. What's the point of you, Michael?
quotation.source: The narrator asks a rhetorical question, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: The little mind games he plays, like reciting the dictionary backwards from memory, fail to amuse him for long. The walls of the world have been torn down and the wind that blows through is cold and preposterous.
quotation.source: The Enigma waits in his room, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: He creates a new language, a new grammar, eight cases and five genders. This passes twenty minutes. Then it's boredom again...
quotation.source: The Enigma kills time, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: Boredom, ennui, absurdity. His closest, his only friends... It looks like there's nothing for him to do but get dressed.
quotation.source: Getting ready, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: He couldn't face Sandra this morning. Crept out without saying goodbye. There's a dent on the hood of his car. There's a green lizard floating across the road.
quotation.source: Michael's commute is interrupted, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: You see, you're all wrong. My name isn't Brain Eater. I am the Head. And I don't simply eat brains. It's something deeper than that. Something magical. Something transubstantiational. Excuse me one moment while I ... <shlurppp>
quotation.source: The first villain, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: Many primitive [*] peoples believe that if you eat a person's brains, you acquire his knowledge.
[*] Footnote: A primitive person is one who doesn't drive a car. Cars are among the greatest causes of premature deaths of lizards in Arizona.
quotation.source: Digressing, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: When the honey of another's life touches my nervous system I could almost be sucking on God's little finger.
quotation.source: The Head, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: As soon as Roger saw the costume, his mind assumed the proportions of an industrial revolution unaware of the ecological damage it was causing.
quotation.source: The origin of the Head, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: His first victim was a priest. Roger's senses were blessed with furtive longings and sweet altar wine.
quotation.source: The Head's backstory, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: I am the Head and I demand your shrunken experiences now!
quotation.source: In ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: What do you think? Which has a better, a more sublimely developed, sense of the ridiculous? Life? Or death? Or me? Or Michael Smith?
quotation.source: A rhetorical question, in ENIGMA #1: "The Lizard, The Head, The Enigma"

quotation.p: If it wasn't for the fact that a monster called the Head was plunging a metal pipe up his nose preparatory to sucking his brains out, Michael Smith could almost laugh.
quotation.source: Opening sentence of ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: At last he's got it. He's got the joke. The joke is life. The punchline is that there are so many things he'd like to do with his life, now that his life is over. Not much of a joke. Not much of a life.
quotation.source: Michael Smith makes his peace, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: I know who you are, he thinks. You're my old secret pal... You're the Enigma, he thinks... And then dies.
quotation.source: The protagonist dies, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: "But as the papers say, he's caught the public's imagination."
"Didn't know they had any."
quotation.source: Cops, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: He sits quite still for two days, forgetting to move. Remembering the previous two days with such precision that it takes fully two days to remember them... remembering with such clarity that he forgets for a while that this is a memory and not the thing remembered.
quotation.source: The Enigma kills more time, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: Is this enough? Does this make it worthwhile? Does this make it less absurd? With these actions can I recreate the dark and sensible walls of an abandoned well?
quotation.source: The Enigma wonders, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: He took the Head in his arms and looked into the eyes, looking for recognition, meaning, something, and seeing only madness and death, bashed his head open.
quotation.source: The Enigma recollects, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: ... lies and half-truths and deceits. Our society is built on them. Our churches and schools and politicians deal in them. Your entire lives are awash with them.
quotation.source: The Truth, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: "Who among you can claim to be honest? Who does not lie? You? Do you claim to be honest?"
"Ahhh, I just work here, sir."
quotation.source: The Truth and a security guard, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: "If you could step outside..."
"There is no outside. There is no inside or outside, no up or down, when it comes to the truth."
quotation.source: A security guard and the Truth, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: For a moment he hesitates, memories stirring. Another life, another person. Suntans, lies and half-truths, a wife, a mistress, the clandestine clinic for cocaine dependency... A package arriving one morning containing a see-through, a brutually honest see-through body stocking...
quotation.source: The Truth falters, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: The Truth fixes the unlucky man with a stare of such dismal honesty that the complex layers of lies and illusions on which the man's life is based fall away, one by one, leaving in their place all that is left once the lies have gone... nothing.
quotation.source: The Truth's modus operandi, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: Should we say any words? We can't just turn him off like he was a microwave or something.
quotation.source: Sandra watches Michael's life support being turned off, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: Look at me. Look into my eyes. See the bitter truth of your life reflected in them. All those lonely nights. All those nasty thoughts. You're the actor. You're the one playing a character who is a lie!
quotation.source: The Truth kills again, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: For a second he feels almost solid. Almost as though he were a real person in a real world.
quotation.source: The Enigma pauses a moment, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: The ants scurrying about, busily feeding, fighting, collecting, building, dying. The lizards watching the world as though they're wise, but they're not wise, just ugly enough to be wise.
quotation.source: Further reflections, in ENIGMA #2: "The Truth"

quotation.p: It's like the book of Revelations, but funnier. It's like the Last Trumpet, but hopelessly out of tune. It's like the perennial battle between good and evil but no one can quite work out which is which anymore, and most people don't even know what perennial means.
quotation.source: Opening lines of ENIGMA #3: "The Good Boy"

quotation.p: The Truth has entered the church. He broke in a few hours ago and gave a sermon on the kind of truths you won't find in any book. Good, bad, or indifferent. Thirty-five believers, ten agnostics and two closet Satanists kicked the Eucharist.
quotation.source: The Truth strikes again, in ENIGMA #3: "The Good Boy"

quotation.p: But look at these others. The Enigmatics, they call themselves. Did these apes lose most of their brains when they lost most of their hair? They can't wait to leave their parents, then once they've left them, can't wait to find new and bigger parents to obey.
quotation.source: The Enigma spawns a cult, in ENIGMA #3: "The Good Boy"

quotation.p: My own characters have come to life to get me, I thought. I should have been nicer to them.
quotation.source: Titus Bird, in ENIGMA #3: "The Good Boy"

quotation.p: Dad died in the last big earthquake to hit Pacific. It was like, after that, Mom was scared of anything chaotic in our lives. Like everything was on the edge of collapsing, getting sucked into an earthquake of chaos.
quotation.source: Michael talks about his parents, in ENIGMA #3: "The Good Boy"

quotation.p: "Someone, I think John Cage, said that life without order was chaos, but order without life was death."
"Who's John Cage?"
"It doesn't matter."
quotation.source: Titus and Michael, in ENIGMA #3: "The Good Boy"

quotation.p: Hey, Michael, you really don't want to go in there. No, really you don't. The Truth hurts, you know...
quotation.source: Closing lines of ENIGMA #3: "The Good Boy"

quotation.p: "Are you ready for me? Are you ready for my indifference? For my abysmal disinterest? Are you ready to have the lies and conceits of your life peeled away like so many layers of skin? Are you ready for the truth?"
"Ahhh... No, I... I don't really think I am..."
quotation.source: The Truth and Michael Smith, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: Too bad. The truth is a rude guest. The truth doesn't knock on the door and wait to be asked in.
quotation.source: The Truth, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: Look into my eyes. You will see the dull horror of your childhood and we will begin to dissect this pointless obsession of yours.
quotation.source: The Truth, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: When he opens his eyes he finds himself in a nightmare world surrounded by nightmare creatures with grotesque ovoid heads and wildly flapping limbs. Michael tells the policemen he remembers nothing.
quotation.source: Aftermath, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: Exactly the Truth is being carted out, to the cheers of the crowd, who obviously fail to see the irony of the Truth dying in a church. Actually, I fail to see the irony in that too, but who cares what I think? I mean, do I really care what you think? Who are you anyway? I mean, are you following any of this?
quotation.source: The narrator gets tetchy, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: Someone has broken into his house and completely rearranged the furniture. And as he looks at the room, now so grotesquely unfamiliar, it's as though something breaks into John's head, and completely rearranges the furniture there.
quotation.source: John Cade's doom, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: "TV and papers are full of it. They creep into homes and rearrange the furniture."
"My God! The monsters!"
quotation.source: Titus and Michael discuss the Interior League, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: It seems they rearrange the furniture in such a way that somehow, God knows how, it drives at least one member of the household crazy. Like the furniture arranged in this pattern is a key that unlocks the mind...
quotation.source: Titus explains the Interior League, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: Like so many others who have abandoned jobs, families, commitments; who chucked in the whole caboodle, torn up their past lives and all they'd thought important to seek out Envelope Girl. All captivated by her strong manila arms, her lovely gumminess, the heady allure of her zip code.
quotation.source: An aging judge's description, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: Returned to his place, he sits quite still, pretending he doesn't exist, which is a harder game than you might imagine.
quotation.source: The Enigma kills yet more time, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: Oh great. Charlie Manson is on my side. Things are really looking up.
quotation.source: Titus Bird, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: You know what impresses me about you? Your ability to be as pathetic as you are and not want to kill yourself. If I were you, I'd have to kill myself.
quotation.source: The Enigma talks to the rich cat, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: What does it mean, huh? What does it mean when those kids die so... pointlessly? It doesn't mean anything, does it? That's the scary part. If it meant something, you could handle it, but it doesn't.
quotation.source: Titus Bird, in ENIGMA #4: "And Then What?"

quotation.p: Look, they're carrying the corpses away, ho hum.
quotation.source: Opening line of ENIGMA #5: "Lizards and Ghosts"

quotation.p: Do I sound detached? Indifferent? I'm not, believe me. I'll tell you a secret: I'm not a distant narrator, aloof from the action of this story... I'm a part of this story.
quotation.source: The narrator drops a hint, in ENIGMA #5: "Lizards and Ghosts"

quotation.p: It's the following day and two more houses have been redecorated by the Interior League. Five people dead.
quotation.source: Events continue to flow, in ENIGMA #5: "Lizards and Ghosts"

quotation.p: But somehow lizards are connected to all this. They're a constant theme.
quotation.source: Michael Smith, in ENIGMA #5: "Lizards and Ghosts"

quotation.p: What are we doing in this suburban living room? And look at that furniture, for God's sake!
quotation.source: The narrator comments on decor, in ENIGMA #5: "Lizards and Ghosts"

quotation.p: The eyes burn with all the wet violence of the young and all the dry malevolence of the old. ... This creature will play a big part in our story, you wait.
quotation.source: Foreshadowing, in ENIGMA #5: "Lizards and Ghosts"

quotation.p: Molesters and foul abusers of comfy chairs and imitation Edwardian sideboards, deflowerers of teak coffee tables and meek landscape paintings and ...
quotation.source: The Interior League described, in ENIGMA #5: "Lizards and Ghosts"

quotation.p: This of course is nothing like the comic book Enigma. This is real life, or as real as your life gets, anyway.
quotation.source: Violence, in ENIGMA #5: "Lizards and Ghosts"

quotation.p: Of course I'm here. I've always been here, there, and everywhere.
quotation.source: Envelope Girl sounds rather Kosh-like, in ENIGMA #5: "Lizards and Ghosts"

quotation.p: My mother laid flowers on the ground above here. Seagulls flew off with them, before the crappy little makeshift service was even finished. Everything was against us. My poor old dad. The ground swallowed him and then the sky stole his flowers. Poor old dad.
quotation.source: Michael Smith in the tomb, in ENIGMA #6: "The End of The World"

quotation.p: I lost my Enigma comics too. They were buried with him and I used to imagine him like an Egyptian pharaoh, buried with what he needed for the afterlife, reading The Enigma for all eternity.
quotation.source: Michael Smith, in ENIGMA #6: "The End of The World"

quotation.p: "I'm whoever you want me to be."
"No, sorry. That's the kind of tacky, bogus line that Titus used to come up with. It works okay on the page but just doesn't sound real when it's spoken."
quotation.source: The Enigma and Michael, in ENIGMA #6: "The End of The World"

quotation.p: People move in and out of other people's lives, and no one ever knows exactly what other people are thinking. In this way we are all alone. But I am more alone than most.
quotation.source: The narrator, in ENIGMA #7: "Sex in Arizona"

quotation.p: He had a charming lightness of touch as he transfixed the young doctor, neatly stripped him, and prepared to devour him, smelly toes first. Of course they hadn't told him that he wasn't allowed to eat the doctors: they'd just arrogantly presumed he wouldn't.
quotation.source: Opening lines of ENIGMA #8: "Queer"

quotation.p: I think we should just be silent for one moment here, and contemplate this waste of reptilian life. Excuse me, are you still there? I haven't lost you yet, have I?
quotation.source: The narrator is uncharacteristically moved, in ENIGMA #8: "Queer"

quotation.p: It's my belief that if you cut into a thing deeply enough; if your incisions are precise and persistent and conducted methodically, then you may reveal not only that thing's inner workings, but also the meaning behind those workings. This conviction was shared by the historical personage whose life is central to From Hell, although perhaps his beliefs were expressed in a somewhat broader sense than my own. For my part, the thing that I am concerned with cutting into and examining is the stillwarm corpse of history itself. In my chilliest moments, I sometimes suspect that this was his foremost preoccupation also, albeit in pursuit of different ends.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In the Appendix of From Hell:The Compleat Scripts

quotation.p: This book is dedicated to Polly Nichols, Annie Chapman, Liz Stride, Kate Eddowes, and Marie Jeanette Kelly. You and your demise: of these things alone are we certain. Goodnight, ladies.
quotation.source: Dedication in the TPB of FROM HELL

quotation.p: "The working class don't want a revolution, Mr Lees: they just want more money."
quotation.source: Abberline, in the prologue to FROM HELL

quotation.p: "Don't you ever feel guilty? We could have said something. We could have done something. Why, Fred? Why did we just let them bury it?"
"Because we didn't want our throats cut. Because we didn't want our lights hung over our shoulders."
quotation.source: Lees and Abberline, in the prologue to FROM HELL

quotation.p: "Well, if I may not work the ocean I should like to work with something of a kind to it... something that flows like the ocean... something salt and old."
quotation.source: Gull, as a child, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "Though concerning the objects of your pity I fear there's little hope."
"There must be... even for such unfortunates. Is not all base matter gradually ascending; refining itself into pure spirit?"
"Assuredly... but some wretches have a downward momentum in their lives almost impossible to reverse."
quotation.source: Gull and Hinton, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "Consider it: water will of necessity flow downhill, thwarting all our best efforts that it should do otherwise. In order that water might rise despite itself it must first be transmuted into steam. It must first be touched by the purifying spirit of fire."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "Dorset Street -- the most evil in London, I'm told."
quotation.source: Hinton, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "Such minds, Hinton, shaping infinity itself."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "Fourth dimensional patterns within Eternity's monolith would, he suggests, seem merely random events to third-dimensional percipients."
quotation.source: Hinton, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "Let us say something peculiar happens in 1788... a century later, related events take place. Then again, 50 years later. Then 25 years. Then 12. An invisible curve, rising through the centuries."
quotation.source: Hinton, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "Can history then be said to have an architecture, Hinton? The notion is most glorious and most horrible."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "Such purpose. I am fifty, my own purpose unrevealed despite meaningless laurels."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "Our son is a wastrel and a halfwit. We shudder to think of the throne in his hands. But he is none the less of our flesh and our obligation is most severe..."
quotation.source: Queen Victoria, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "These times, they are a worry to us, and it has been too long since we had men about us who were strong and dependable. Since dear, dear Albert... Go. Go now, Dr Gull. We would be alone."
quotation.source: Queen Victoria, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "There is a wrong, an intense wrong, in our society running all through our life... And it will be made righter some day. I dashed myself against it but it is no one man's strength can move it. It was too much for my brain, but it is by the failure of some that others succeed, and through my very foolishness shall come better success to others... perhaps more than any cleverness of mine could have wrought."
quotation.source: James Hinton, quoted in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "Fear not, though thoughts and memories most unendurable beset your mind... for I shall take them all away and quite relieve your suffering."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "Less then a thimble-full of iodine divides the intellectual from the imbecile. Of which phenomenon I shall forthwith attempt a demonstration."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #2

quotation.p: "I dreamed about Stamford Street, where I lived with my Billy before 'e ran off..."
"Dreams! It's wakin' life's the trouble!"
quotation.source: Polly Nichols and Annie Chapman, in FROM HELL #3

quotation.p: "No, sir! Not "Done away with" for that is common murder, only fit for common footpads. I spoke of grand work, Netley. Grand work. A great work must have many sides from which we may consider it."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #4

quotation.p: "Do you begin to grasp how truly great a work is London? A veritable textbook we may draw upon in formulating great works of our own!"
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #4

quotation.p: "The greater part of London's story is not writ in words. It is instead a literature of stone, of place-names and assocations."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #4

quotation.p: "Symbols have power, Netley... Power enough to turn even a stomach such as yours, or to deliver half this planet's population into slavery."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #4

quotation.p: "Do whatever needs to be done. You make your cuts, Sir Charles. I'll make mine."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #5

quotation.p: "What a life you have endured, awaiting nothing but deliverance."
"Mm. I... Sir? I feel so queer. Does everything look sparkly to you?"
"Why, child, that's just the stars. This is a rare and special night, I think. For both of us."
quotation.source: Gull and Polly Nichols, in FROM HELL #5

quotation.p: "You're forging a letter from a killer? But that's ..."
"It's a whole new style of journalism, Mr Gibbs, and we're inventin' it right 'ere in Wapping."
quotation.source: Mr Best and Mr Gibbs, in FROM HELL #7

quotation.p: "Oh God. I've been tryin' not to think about it. I had such a lovely fuck with Joe last night. I thought "Is this it? Is this the last of it?"
quotation.source: Mary Kelly, in FROM HELL #8

quotation.p: "Gull, please, in the name of reason..."
"Invoke not reason. In the end it is too small a deity."
quotation.source: Sir Charles Warren and Gull, in FROM HELL #8

quotation.p: "It... ughh... it is these grapes. They have something on them, I think."
"'tis laudanum. A little, nothing more. They are the grapes of mercy, child, not lightly spat away."
quotation.source: Elizabeth Stride and Gull, in FROM HELL #8

quotation.p: "If you'll forgive me, Sir, I am Robert Lees, psychic adviser to Her Majesty. I am familiar with your work, Sir, and have long anticipated this meeting."
"Indeed? I am similarly familiar with your work , Sir, profiting from delusions born of bereavement. Consequently, I have relished this meeting not at all. Good day."
quotation.source: Robert Lees and Gull, in FROM HELL #9

quotation.p: "Say what you will, Sir. You are welcome to remain ensconced in lore and ritual. For my part I am happy to entertain a questioning spirit."
"Ha ha ha! Then mark my words, Mr Yeats, your bones shall never rest easy. Good day to you, Sir."
quotation.source: W.B. Yeats and Gull, in FROM HELL #9

quotation.p: "Oh, an' I see Anderson's back from 'is Swiss 'olidays, ayin' we should arrest every tart for 'er own protection!"
"Well, he's one of them Second-Coming Christians, ain't he? Perhaps he'll put some of them up at his house."
quotation.source: Abberline and Godley, in FROM HELL #9

quotation.p: "There, there, Netley. There, there. I shall tell you where we are. We're in the most extreme and utter region of the human mind, a dim sub-conscious underworld. A radiant abyss where men meet themselves... Hell, Netley. We're in Hell."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #9

quotation.p: "You're mad."
"Oh, undoubtedly. But you're helpless."
quotation.source: Sir Charles Warren and Gull, in FROM HELL #9

quotation.p: "Dear God, what is this Aethyr I am come upon? What spirits are these, labouring in what heavenly light? No... No, this is dazzle, but not yet divinity."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #10

quotation.p: "It would seem we are to suffer an apocalypse of cockatoos... Morose, barbaric children, playing joylessly with their unfathomable toys."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #10

quotation.p: "Where comes this dullness in your eyes? How has your century numbed you so? Shall man be given marvels only when he is beyond all wonder?
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #10

quotation.p: "You are the sum of all preceding you, yet seem indifferent to yourselves. A culture grown disinterested, even in its own abysmal wounds."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #10

quotation.p: "Ah, Mary, how time's levelled us. We are made equal, both mere curios of our vanished epoch in this lustless world. This world, where in comparison I am made ignorant, while you... you are made virtuous."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #10

quotation.p: "Do you understand how I have loved you? You'd have all been dead in a year or two from liver failure, men, or childbirth. Dead. Forgotten. I have saved you. Do you understand that? I have made you safe from time, and we are wed in legend, inextricable within eternity."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #10

quotation.p: "Have you done, Sir? Is it finished with?"
"It is beginning, Netley. Only just beginning. For better or worse, the twentieth century."
quotation.source: Netley and Gull, in FROM HELL #10

quotation.p: "I have been climbing, Netley, all my life, toward a single peak. Now I have reached it. I have stood and felt the wind. I have seen all the world beneath me. Now there is only descent. Only the valley. Would that I had died there, Netley, in that light above the cloud line. I'm cold. Take me home."
quotation.source: Gull, in FROM HELL #10

quotation.p: "I remember my first Fenian bombin', year afore I were first married. Makes you think there's naught to us but shit and mincemeat."
quotation.source: Abberline, in FROM HELL #11

quotation.p: "To be honest, I felt worse than sick. I came out that room and I felt somethin' bad 'ad 'appened. Not just to 'er, to everythin'. I felt as if everythin' were lost."
quotation.source: Abberline, in FROM HELL #11

quotation.p: "Come on, Godley. Cheer up, for fuck's sake. There's good things happen in life as well, y'know."
"But... I mean, after that ... that thing in Miller's Court."
"I said in life, Godley. I didn't say in the East End."
quotation.source: Abberline and Godley, in FROM HELL #11

quotation.p: "Ah, yes. Dear Frank. I'm afraid he's had to retire early with a mild touch of insanity."
quotation.source: Oscar Wilde, in FROM HELL #11

quotation.p: "Oscar Wilde? Oscar Wilde, the writer?"

"Oh, good heavens, no! Awful fellow. Wouldn't give him house- room. No, I'm Oscar Wilde the florist. While over here we have Mr Walter Sickert, the turf accountant... and Mr James McNeil Whistler, who I believe keeps a tripe stall in Mile End."
quotation.source: Montague Druitt and Oscar Wilde, in FROM HELL #11

quotation.p: "It's all just stories when all's said and done."
"But that's just the thing, it isn't just stories. Those women really died. And poor Druitt, caught up in something he could never understand."
"That's all done with though. That's all gone."
quotation.source: Abberline and Robert Lees, in the epilogue to FROM HELL

quotation.p: "Take my advice and don't get old. It's bloody rubbish."
quotation.source: Abberline, in the epilogue to FROM HELL

quotation.p: "Now there's just us, knowin' what we know, both washed up 'ere. Can't send a message; can't tell anybody. I expect there's been a lot of chaps in our position down across the years with one thing and another. Makes you wonder, sometimes, doesn't it? Make you wonder 'ow much of the world is true."
quotation.source: Abberline, in the epilogue to FROM HELL

quotation.p: "I think there's going to be another war."
quotation.source: Robert Lees, in the epilogue to FROM HELL

quotation.p: The problem we face here is that neither Knight nor the assembled ranks of Freemasonry are necessarily telling the truth, at which point a Victorian fog starts to engulf the facts of our narrative. Given that the tortuous story of the Whitechapel murders is filled with liars, tricksters, and unreliable witnesses, it is a fog we shall encounter often.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In Appendix I of FROM HELL

quotation.p: The character and temperament of Victoria here is entirely my own interpretation, and has indeed been the source of debate between myself and the otherwise genial and agreeable Mr Campbell of Brisbane, Australia.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In Appendix I of FROM HELL

quotation.p: One almost suspects that the bereaved Victoria, who spent the later decades of her reign in mourning for her departed consort, would have changed her own name to Albert and the name of the country to Alberta if she had thought for a moment she could get away with it.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In Appendix I of FROM HELL

quotation.p: The phrase, Hairy-Ford-Shire, a rather dim pun upon the pronunciation of "Hertfordshire", is one of an extensive array of Victorian slang expressions relating to the female genitalia. The expression, in this instance, was passed on to me by Mr Neil Gaiman, who has a dirty mouth in at least seven centuries.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In Appendix I of FROM HELL

quotation.p: As with so much of From Hell, when we know the details of a person's life but not how he or she felt, then we must resort to fiction unless we are to exclude feelings altogether, which I don't feel inclined to do.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In Appendix I of FROM HELL

quotation.p: In the case of the fraudulent and press-generated "Ripper" letters, we see a clear prototype of the current British tabloid press in action, and for this reason it seemed poetically apposite that the letter be composed in Wapping, currently the home of Mr Rupert Murdoch's highly popular right-wing tabloid, which, unsurprisingly in this tale of obelisks and other arcane solar symbols, is called The Sun.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In Appendix I of FROM HELL

quotation.p: On the 29th September, the Central News Agency forwarded the letter to Scotland Yard that we see Abberline reading aloud here to Thick and Godley (and if there were ever two names more emblematic of the police force of that period, I should certainly like to hear them).
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In Appendix I of FROM HELL

quotation.p: Abberline's eerily precognitive comments on page two are my own invention. They are also, in their way, a form of shamefaced apology from one currently making part of his living wrapping up miserable little killings in supernatural twaddle. Sometimes, after all you've done for them, your characters just turn on you.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In Appendix I of FROM HELL

quotation.p: Everyone seems agreed that Kelly was the real target. She'd infected Dr Stanley's son, corrupted Olga Tchkersoff's sister. The underlying assumption remains unstated: she must have done something to deserve that.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: By Autumn 1988 I'm thinking of seriously about writing something lengthy on a murder. The Whitechapel killings aren't even considered. Too played-out. Too obvious. Publicity around the crimes' centennial, however, leads me to Knight's book. Ideas coalesce. Deciding on a serial in Steve Bissette's Taboo, I contact Eddie Campbell. The rest is dodgy pseudo-history.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: Be vewy, vewy quiet. We're hunting Wippers.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: Slowly it dawns on me that despite the Gull theory's obvious attractions, the idea of a solution, any solution, is inane. Murder isn't like books. Murder, a human event located in both space and time, has an imaginary field completely unrestrained by either. It holds meaning, and shape, but no solution.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: The grounds of the enquiry are a forensic sucking-bog; treacherous, obsessional. Fall in this stuff and you won't come out again.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: Reputedly, many prominent Ripperologists never set foot in Whitechapel for fear of being mugged. Mugging's not the danger here. This place is authentically dreadful.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: It isn't getting drawn into Masonic Death Conspiracy that troubles me, you understand. It's getting drawn into the vortex of a fiction.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: Some stories just don't have what it takes. The yarn that eventually survives to be accepted as history will do so by brute Darwinian mechanics. We'll lock all the suspects in a room together. They can fight it out.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: Our detective fictions tell us otherwise: everything's just meat and cold ballistics. Provide a murderer, a motive, and a means, you've solved the crime. Using this method, the solution to the Second World War is as follows: Hitler. The German economy. Tanks. Thus, for convenience, we reduce the complex events.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: The greater part of any murder is the field of theory, fascination and hysteria that it engenders. A black diaspora. Our tireless, sinister enthusiasm.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: Soon, somebody will notice the disturbing similarities between the Ripper crimes and recent cattle mutilations, from which they will draw the only sensible conclusion.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: Likewise, each new book provides fresh details, finer crennelations of the subject's edge. Its area, however, can't extend past the initial circle: Autumn, 1888, Whitechapel. ... Koch's Snowflake: gaze upon it, Ripperologists, and shiver.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: The complex phantom we project. That alone, we know is real. The actual killer's gone, unglimpsed. Might as well not have been there at all. There never was a Jack the Ripper. Mary Kelly was just an unusually determined suicide. Why don't we leave it there?
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: It's going. It's all going. Will anybody bother with a bicentennial in 2088? Might our pursuit, our quarry, already endangered, be by then extinct?
We were looking at the naked woman dancing when it flew away.
quotation.author: Alan Moore
quotation.source: In "Dance of the Gull-Catchers" in FROM HELL

quotation.p: Childbirth is not a miracle. Life is not sacred. When you have twenty thousand nomads huddled between two rivers in the Middle East and that's it for Homo sapiens, when one in five children is a live birth, one in ten living past the age of ten, then childbirth is a miracle and life is sacred. When the average age of a grandmother in Philadelphia's housing projects is twenty-five, to call childbirth a miracle is at least a tasteless joke and at worst a true obscenity.
quotation.author: Dave Sim
quotation.source: In the lettercol of Cerebus #142

quotation.p: Do not wander off without me. That's how we lost Amelia Earhart in here. Every day, about two in the afternoon, the thermals are right, and we hear her somewhere in here, screaming for peanut buttter and jelly sandwiches.
quotation.source: Harlan's our genial guide through HARLAN ELLISON'S DREAM CORRIDOR Special.

quotation.p: You'd have liked my father. He was a sweet guy. He died when I was fourteen, but when I was a little kid we used to sit together and I'd read my comic books to him. I don't think he cared much about the silly stuff in comics -- that was the '40s -- but he loved me and took pleasure in my reading aloud to him. I miss my dad.
quotation.source: Harlan remembers his childhood, in HARLAN ELLISON'S DREAM CORRIDOR #2

quotation.p: But, if you have a moment, if your heart is big enough to spare a moment, give a nod and a smile for all the good ones who spent their lives making great art and small art and even entertainment. When they're gone, there's only one way to tell them you miss them... Send them a moment of kind thought right now. The beam will pick it up and carry it across the stars to them where they wait. I've been sending good wishes to the ones I miss all evening. Now it's your turn.
quotation.source: Harlan's soliloquy in HARLAN ELLISON'S DREAM CORRIDOR #5

quotation.p: When I say that Seth will have his testicles torn off, I do not mean that his sac will always be a ragged void. If the gods are not exactly a law unto themselves, they can at least bend the rules. In other words, some balls bounce back.
quotation.source: Peter Milligan's opening sentences in EGYPT #1

quotation.p: I had it in me to be the Pierce Brosnan of my generation.
quotation.source: Vincent Me's past career plans in EGYPT #1

quotation.p: Vincent, you are a damaged person who uses sexual gratification as a displacement activity. Now get your hand off my behind.
quotation.source: Ooh, good putdown! in EGYPT #1

quotation.p: I simply reject the capitalist credo. I reject anything that ends in 'ist' or 'ism'. In fact, I reject anything that ends in 's'.
quotation.source: Is Vincent for real? In EGYPT #1

quotation.p: Years later I was regaining consciousness in America, which is no mean feat.
quotation.source: Waking from memories of a sister, in EGYPT #1

quotation.p: "The Order of Osiris, the Order of the Listless One, oh God of Yesterday, He-Who-Is-Awakened, Lord of the Chennet, the suffering god from whose inert body..."
"I've got Latin in four hours, Josh. Let's get on with it."
"Oh, sorry, of course. Got a little carried away..."
quotation.source: My college years weren't like this! In EGYPT #1

quotation.p: "We got to thinking: how did the priests know exactly how long to suffocate the new pharaoh for?"
"Ah, ah, preposition at the end of a sentence, Kim. You owe me a dollar."
quotation.source: Kim and Bobby in EGYPT #1

quotation.p: Three hundred years of tears have soured the very stones of this house. Drink deep, gentle reader: you have come too far to turn back now.
quotation.source: Bethlehem Hospital, or Bedlam, in SEBASTIAN O #1

quotation.p: But we cannot disguise our abhorrence of modern communication devices.
quotation.source: Queen Victoria on teleconferencing, in SEBASTIAN O #1

quotation.p: The dandy has one unique advantage over the common herd. No matter what the situation, he will always be more exquisitely dressed than his enemies. Therefore, he has already triumphed.
quotation.source: Sebastian, in SEBASTIAN O #1

quotation.p: One must commit acts of the highest treason only when dressed in the most resplendent finery.
quotation.source: Sebastian, in SEBASTIAN O #1

quotation.p: We may be in the sewer, but there's absolutely no need for that kind of gutter profanity.
quotation.source: Sebastian, in SEBASTIAN O #2

quotation.p: If I know Sebastian, he'll find it impossible to continue his mission in soiled clothing.
quotation.source: Lord Lavender, in SEBASTIAN O #2

quotation.p: And now let us hasten to the station. I have commanded the rain to fall at exactly one-fifteen and I would hate to get my shoes wet.
quotation.source: Lord Lavender, in SEBASTIAN O #2

quotation.p: I do so loathe nature, don't you? All that dreadful rot and decay and procreation. Here, everything is so much more tidy. I simply wind the trees once a day and reset the flowers.
quotation.source: The Abb does love his clockwork garden, in SEBASTIAN O #2

quotation.p: It would take days to catalog your sins, Abb. I simply don't have the time.
quotation.source: Sebastian, in SEBASTIAN O #2

quotation.p: The Abb, I'm afraid, has gone to meet his maker. Hard to decide which of the two will receive the greater shock.
quotation.source: Sebastian, in SEBASTIAN O #3

quotation.p: "Don't fret, Theo. The lad's simply stunned. He'll wake up in an hour, none the wiser."
"But his throat has been cut."
"Oh, dear, my mistake. My diagnosis regarding his recovery would appear to have been somewhat premature."
quotation.source: Sebastian and Lord Lavender, in SEBASTIAN O #3

quotation.p: First... a pardon. I should hate to be hounded further for acts which some might consider crimes, but which I prefer to think of as aesthetic statements. I have, after all, killed only the very dull.
quotation.source: Sebastian, in SEBASTIAN O #3

quotation.p: One hardly requires the abilities of a Tiresias to predict fog in London. What other revelations have you to offer, Theo? That the Grand National will be won by a horse this year, perhaps?
quotation.source: Sebastian, in SEBASTIAN O #3

quotation.p: We're beginning to think it may be a neurological disorder, similar to Tourette's Syndrome. It's quite possible we may be looking at some kind of super-sanity here. A brilliant new modification of human perception, more suited to urban life at the end of the twentieth century.
quotation.source: Ruth Adams describes the Joker in ARKHAM ASYLUM

quotation.p: You must be feeling quite fragile by now, I expect. This house, it... does things to the mind.
quotation.source: The Mad Hatter in ARKHAM ASYLUM

quotation.p: I pity the poor shades confined to the Euclidean prison that is sanity.
quotation.source: From Amadeus Arkham's journal in ARKHAM ASYLUM

quotation.p: I should say I'm very much cleverer than any of the people who put me here. As a matter of fact, I could leave any time I wanted. It's only a doll's house after all. Anyway, I don't mind. I like dolls. Particularly the live ones.
quotation.source: Mad Hatter's thoughts in ARKHAM ASYLUM

quotation.p: "And if you want something hotter, you know where to find me."
"In the gutter on a Friday night, Tony."
quotation.source: Tony and Annie in THE MYSTERY PLAY

quotation.p: Not every day one has God on the slab, eh?
quotation.source: The coroner in THE MYSTERY PLAY

quotation.p: "God is in the details," after all. Or in this case, perhaps, the details are in God.
quotation.source: The coroner in THE MYSTERY PLAY

quotation.p: I think everything that happens in the vicinity of a murder has some significance: the flight of birds, the shape of the clouds, the positions of the stars, items discarded by passersby. Nothing can be overlooked. If I find a match, I have to know where it was made and from what tree its wood was taken.
quotation.source: The detective in THE MYSTERY PLAY

quotation.p: I'm not a metaphysical man. I'm a minister. That's my job.
quotation.source: The minister in THE MYSTERY PLAY

quotation.p: I was somebody else once. I... I... don't think I was a very good person.
quotation.source: The detective in THE MYSTERY PLAY

quotation.p: "The killer's still out there, Mr Purves. I hope Christ has taken out life insurance."
"Oh, I'm sure any firm would jump at the chance to ensure a man who has eternal life, don't you?"
quotation.source: The detective and the mayor in THE MYSTERY PLAY

quotation.p: Well, me whole family's musical, Jeffo... even the sewing machine's a Singer.
quotation.source: John Constantine in HELLBLAZER #90

quotation.p: It's a little-known legend is Abaton -- the town of changing locations. Philosophers, mystics and clever-bastards-in-general have known of its existence for centuries.
quotation.source: In HELLBLAZER #93

quotation.p: As I follow the green man up the narrow path, visions of electric hedge trimmers go swimming through my brain.
quotation.source: John Constantine in HELLBLAZER #93

quotation.p: You are in a beautifully wooded area covered with flowers, blah-blah- blah...
quotation.source: John Constantine in HELLBLAZER #93

quotation.p: If Abaton's the unearthly reflection of all that we are, Britain's in far worse shape than I thought.
quotation.source: John Constantine in HELLBLAZER #93

quotation.p: I've always believed that guilt was an emotion for weaker men -- so where does that leave me?
quotation.source: Wesley Dodds, in SANDMAN MYSTERY THEATRE: "The Cannon", act I

quotation.p: Ah, love... so much better than the alternative.
quotation.source: Rev. Hawsley, in SANDMAN MYSTERY THEATRE: "The Cannon", act I

quotation.p: He's clouds or fires now.
quotation.source: The Cannon finds Donald Eversoll's body, in SANDMAN MYSTERY THEATRE: "The Cannon", act II

quotation.p: Good news is he don't have to go to work tomorrow. Bad news is the same.
quotation.source: Lt. Burke finds Donald Eversoll's body, in SANDMAN MYSTERY THEATRE: "The Cannon", act II

quotation.p: "I'm surprised you don't think justice is best left to higher powers, Bagsy?"
"I do, Dian -- I just want to make sure He knows where to look."
quotation.source: Dian and Rev. Hawsley, in SANDMAN MYSTERY THEATRE: "The Cannon", act IV

quotation.p: "And are your Lord's lessons learned in you, Cannon?"
"I am confident that I will pass through St. Peter's gates with only minor negotiations."
quotation.source: The Sandman and the Cannon, in SANDMAN MYSTERY THEATRE: "The Cannon", act IV

quotation.p: Good job, there, O'Grady. Always kick 'em when they're down. You might just make a detective yet.
quotation.source: Lt. Burke, in SANDMAN MYSTERY THEATRE: "The Cannon", act IV

quotation.p: There are very few people who directly touch my daily life -- and I can't imagine how much poorer I'd be without any of them.
quotation.source: Wesley Dodds, in SANDMAN MYSTERY THEATRE: "The City", act I

quotation.p: I was happy in that field. I could have stayed there forever. I liked life in those days. I thought life was my best friend.
I was a happy little idiot, really.
quotation.source: Kathy, in SHADE #1: "Execution Day"

quotation.p: I read a pamphlet on alcohol abuse once. It said alcohol turns you into a different person. I thought, "Great! That's for me!" But it was no good. You always wake up or sober up the same person. With a headache.
quotation.source: Kathy, in SHADE #1: "Execution Day"

quotation.p: Shade said all the madness inside people's heads will be released, made real. The sky looks really weird today. The colors look wrong. The clouds look wrong. Everything looks wrong. Welcome to the madhouse.
quotation.source: Kathy, in SHADE #1: "Execution Day"

quotation.p: "I'm your liberated dreams, baby. Your liberated dreams and your unfettered screams..."
"No! I don't want my dreams to be liberated. Our dreams are too terrible to be liberated!"
quotation.source: The American Scream and Duane, in SHADE #2: "Who Shot JFK?"

quotation.p: His teeth will always be perfect, his smile the smile of a sun god, his wife beside him and perfect. Texan sun on the limo's perfect polished bonnet...
quotation.source: From SHADE #2: "Who Shot JFK?"

quotation.p: And out it comes, out it grows. From the womb of Dallas, impregnated by seeds of blood and brain and bone, of conspiracy and deceit, of cowardice and corruption and greed, planted here on a hot bad Friday. Fifteen seconds past 12:30 PM, November 22, 1963...
The Kennedy sphinx... And who shall answer his riddle?
quotation.source: From SHADE #2: "Who Shot JFK?"

quotation.p: So the person chosen to be the leader of your country was murdered, and you had something called the Warren Commission to cover it all up. And the people really responsible were never even named. And the people you employ to protect you, the CIA, the FBI, they actually helped the people responsible to get away with it? And this was a popular president? What happens with an unpopular president? Do you just leave him in the gutter to rot or what?
quotation.source: Shade, in SHADE #2: "Who Shot JFK?"

quotation.p: This sphinx doesn't strangle. This sphinx is the Kennedy sphinx. This sphinx is American. It consumes. It eats.
quotation.source: From SHADE #2: "Who Shot JFK?"

quotation.p: Cancer is rather interesting. I believe it's a kind of wearing out of information. Runaway cells who've forgotten who they are or where they're going. But it mightn't be restricted to creatures or cells. Why not cancer of civilization? Why not cancer of the imagination? Imagine a cancer of reality.
quotation.source: Stringer, in SHADE #2: "Who Shot JFK?"

quotation.p: "Bobby? Jesus... And what about Teddy? They get Teddy, too?"
"Ahhh, no. They didn't need to wipe Teddy out. Teddy was doing a fine job of that himself."
quotation.source: JFK and Duane, in SHADE #3: "All the President's Assassins"

quotation.p: I must be plastic. I must transpose myself into a new and mad view of reality.
quotation.source: Shade, in SHADE #3: "All the President's Assassins"

quotation.p: The past is a branch, forking through and out from Dallas. There's more than one truth, more than one assassin. But behind them all is the same hand, the shadow of the same creature... let's go deeper still...
quotation.source: Mary Ann, in SHADE #3: "All the President's Assassins"

quotation.p: Oh, the Mob and the CIA are just the high priests, the guardians of America's divinity... which is usually green and comes with a picture of Mr. Washington on one side and the words "In God We Trust" on the other...
quotation.source: Mary Ann, in SHADE #3: "All the President's Assassins"

quotation.p: "I say we fly in the choppers, drop a few dozen grenades and swamp the whole area with napalm. See how the big bastard copes with that..."
"You sentimental old liberal, Hopgood. Don't you think we should try the direct approach?"
quotation.source: Hopgood and Stringer, in SHADE #3: "All the President's Assassins"

quotation.p: You know, I've a horrible feeling that if we get much deeper into this madness we're gonna end up having a religious experience. And I vowed long ago never to have one of those.
quotation.source: Kathy, in SHADE #3: "All the President's Assassins"

quotation.p: And I am the American Scream, e pluribus unum, out of many, one... Giver of voice and flesh to the quiet screams of unquiet minds.
quotation.source: The Scream, in SHADE #4: "Mad, Bad, and Dangerous to Know"

quotation.p: I used to stare at flowers, rage at death, cry at sunsets. After my confirmation, I was too sensible for that. I enrolled at college, took my occupational personality test, cried at no more sunsets. I was a dull little bastard, like all the others.
quotation.source: Shade, in SHADE #4: "Mad, Bad, and Dangerous to Know"

quotation.p: And I smile, as a man might smile looking round the ruins of his house, and finding something he thought he'd lost long, long ago.
quotation.source: Shade, in SHADE #4: "Mad, Bad, and Dangerous to Know"

quotation.p: How I enjoy people who refer to themselves in the third person! It's as though they were reciting from their own biography. And a biography of a person is always so much more interesting than the person himself.
quotation.source: Crispin Keen, in SHADE #5: "Hollywood Babble On"

quotation.p: "Yeah, I heard she'd screw a horse if it meant acting with Brando."
"If it'd help her career she'd screw Brando if it meant acting with a horse."
quotation.source: Edward and William, in SHADE #5: "Hollywood Babble On"

quotation.p: "What do you do in America once the money's run out."
"Starve."
quotation.source: Shade and Kathy, in SHADE #5: "Hollywood Babble On"

quotation.p: You can't escape it. Everywhere there are screens, pictures, images, sounds. They won't let you be alone. America is scared of being alone.
quotation.source: From SHADE #5: "Hollywood Babble On"

quotation.p: "But a camera's just a machine. It can't have the madness. That doesn't make sense."
"If it made sense it wouldn't be the madness, would it?"
quotation.source: Kathy and Shade, in SHADE #6: "Hollywood Babble On II"

quotation.p: I must keep a clear head. If I'm to survive with my mind intact, I must put my queer shoulder firmly to the wheel of objectivity.
quotation.source: Crispen Keen, in SHADE #6: "Hollywood Babble On II"

quotation.p: All the years the public lived vicariously through film, now they're living it. But life isn't like film. Life's got too many plot defects. Whom to blame? Who's the director, the auteur of life? Who writes these utterly absurd screenplays? God? But God doesn't exist. And if he does he's more Godard than Spielberg.
quotation.source: Crispen Keen, in SHADE #6: "Hollywood Babble On II"

quotation.p: Guess this changes things, though. If inanimate objects can get the madness... an insane coffee cup. A schizophrenic shirt...
quotation.source: Shade, in SHADE #6: "Hollywood Babble On II"

quotation.p: "Nice tits, by the way."
"Jesus, we got a date with Oscar Wilde..."
quotation.source: Shade and a post-modern prostitute, in SHADE #64

quotation.p: "I think she looks the type that will see through the whole charade."
"Yeah. We're just visible signs of his inner trepidation coupled with a fear of commitment..."
"Excuse me! I said, excuse me! Prostitutes! Ladies of the night! Streetwalkers! I'm talking to you!"
quotation.source: Two post-modern prostitutes and Shade, in SHADE #64

quotation.p: So that's two bottles of bourbon, twenty beers and four clubs to room one oh one... and if it isn't here in fifteen minutes we'll set fire to the hotel.
quotation.source: Andrea Merdoch ordering from room service in SHADE #64

quotation.p: "You mean you want to help the people who've been hurt?"
"Actually, I was thinking more about me and my quality of life. But if people get helped as a byproduct I can live with it."
quotation.source: Sinita and Shade in SHADE #64

quotation.p: Hell... the most awful place you can imagine. Currently under new management, now guaranteed to be even worse.
quotation.source: STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #1

quotation.p: "Zzzxxynax (Spit/Drool) Bite-your-dog's-head-off Zznoq?"
"Here."
quotation.source: Remiel calling attendance in Hell, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #1

quotation.p: Earth... the most awful place you can imagine, if you live in Los Angeles. Other than that, it's pretty neat.
quotation.source: STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #1

quotation.p: "Hey, here's some more stuff from the Bicentennial! (ahem) 'My friends, taxes are too high and the government treats us like idiots, so I'm revolting.'"
"At least you had an excuse."
quotation.source: Stanley and his monster, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #1

quotation.p: "Look, here's a book."
"Not another copy of Jonathan Livingston Seagull, is it?"
quotation.source: Stanley and his monster, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #1

quotation.p: Yum, genuine polyester!
quotation.source: The monster, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #1

quotation.p: Better get going; your parents still think me imaginary, and I'd hate to shatter an illusion like that before dinner.
quotation.source: The monster, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #1

quotation.p: "Take this book back to my room, and don't eat it!"
"Stanley, you wound me. I already have this delicious stack of National Geographics, thank you."
quotation.source: Stanley and his monster, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #1

quotation.p: "Great! Tomorrow we find the right tree!"
"What're our criteria?"
"One you won't break."
quotation.source: Stanley and his monster, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #1

quotation.p: "Hell sounds like a very silly place. Don't you miss it?"
"No. Not even a little, Stanley. You see, we'd... play tricks on each other all the time... but nobody was your friend. Not really. Nobody was anybody's friend."
quotation.source: The monster reminiscing, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #1

quotation.p: That is quite enough. I mean really, Stanley, I'm afraid you've exceeded your special effects budget for this entire month. Not to mention the casting calls I've had to sit through. I'm afraid that you'll be dreaming about the ocean for the next several weeks. I happen to have a lot of it in stock. Perhaps it will calm you down. Good night.
quotation.source: Morpheus, Lord of Dreams, makes a nicely characterized guest appearance in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #1

quotation.p: "So what's so bad about her?"
"To answer that, Stanley, I'd have to tell you about the birds and the bees... and the chainsaws, and the weasels, and the icepicks, and the acid, and the..."
quotation.source: The monster's introduction to his lady-love Nyx, on the cover of STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #2

quotation.p: "Aha! I knew I'd find you here!"
"Huh? Well, good for you. Now it's your turn to hide."
quotation.source: Weevil Dendrite and Ambrose Bierce in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #2

quotation.p: "'Disreputable Urban Magicians and Sorcerors Union' Oh...sorry."
"Ah, s'not your fault. You learn the basics, have a hideous experience in a graveyard, they give you a trenchcoat and steal your razor. Like an assembly line, really."
quotation.source: Weevil Dendrite and Ambrose Bierce in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #2

quotation.p: I've created my own form of divination. One that allows me to capture the currents of chaos in mid-motion and study the fluxes themselves. I call it-- JELLOMANCY!
quotation.source: Weevil Dendrite explains his magic, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #2

quotation.p: "And you're a rhymer now. How... nice."
"Like it? Actually I'm still just apprenticing. They've been starting me off slow. Enchantments, prophecies of doom, greeting cards, stuff like that."
quotation.source: The monster and Nyx, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #2

quotation.p: You'll die gloriously, I promise you. Well, actually, you're going to die slowly and painfully, but it's nothing a little editing won't fix.
quotation.source: A battle-enraged Nyx, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #2

quotation.p: Luckily, every good story is allowed one astounding coincidence. The writer has decided to cash his in now.
quotation.source: In Phil Foglio's STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #2

quotation.p: That does it! I cannot understand why everybody speaks so well of 'subtlety.' It never works, I don't know why I even try anymore!! Now!! Tell me, mortal scum, where is he?!
quotation.source: Nyx throws in the towel, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #2

quotation.p: "Yes, that hideous thing that looked like my wife!"
"I beg your pardon?!"
"But Sheila, I didn't... I mean, she really was lovely--"
"Is that so?"
"But it was a hideous evil sort of lovely!"
quotation.source: Wedded bliss, in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #3

quotation.p: "But what did they call you?"
"'Big-shaggy-red-spirit-dog-who-protects-village.' It's not like there were a lot of us around."
quotation.source: Stanley's mother and the monster in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #3

quotation.p: "I don't think you can fit under the bed."
"Oh, there are some ladies who'd tell you otherwise."
quotation.source: Stanley and Ambrose Bierce in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #3

quotation.p: "Do you happen to know that consciousness is the creature of rhythm?"
"No, but if you hum a few bars..."
"Humf. You are not him."
"(Boy, and I thought the the Church of the Sub-Genius was weird.)"
quotation.source: Stanley's father and a servant of Moxon in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #3

quotation.p: "Okay, we've got all the ingredients for 'spaghetti'. You know, I think this would be pretty good if you threw in some turpentine and a few centipedes."
"I think the first time out we should just stick to the recipe."
quotation.source: The monster and Stanley in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #3

quotation.p: "Where are we, Mr Bierce?"
"There are many realms between the spheres of life and death, Stanley. No magician can explore them all."
"You don't know."
quotation.source: Ambrose Bierce and Stanley in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #4

quotation.p: "I'll be curious to see what he thinks Hell is."
"Garn, I hope he ain't British. Some of that stuff them people dream up... it's enough to gag a maggot."
quotation.source: Demons awaiting Stanley's arrival in Hell in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #4

quotation.p: What kind of theological education are kids getting today?!
quotation.source: An highly-annoyed goofy-looking orange demon in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #4

quotation.p: Bar-B-Q sauce? Damnit, Nyx, what do you think that will do, you ignorant-- Uh-oh. Oh no! Cerberus? Buddy? Good dog?
quotation.source: Glyfford gets a sinking feeling in STANLEY AND HIS MONSTER #4

quotation.p: I'm here for the FBI, not the Weekly World News.
quotation.source: Scully in X-FILES #1

quotation.p: "That isn't the real Shroud of Turin, is it?"
"No, Agent Mulder. Just a replica. I keep the original in the basement, next to the Holy Grail."
quotation.source: Mulder and Mr. Newton in X-FILES #1

quotation.p: "You're off the case! Go chase Bigfoot!
"I'd love to, Sir, but with all due respect, the season is wrong. Bigfoot sightings taper off in the winter. Unless you were suggesting I go to China, where reports of a beast-man are..."
quotation.source: The Smoking Man and Mulder in X-FILES #1

quotation.p: Mulder! We are not alone!
quotation.source: Scully in X-FILES #1

quotation.p: "Everyone else got to read the Fatima prophecy... and all I got was this lousy T-shirt." Thanks. I'll treasure it always.
quotation.source: Mulder gets a Christmas gift from Scully in X-FILES #1

quotation.p: It would be such a relief to think my sister's happy, but when I look up at the heavens, all I see are the stars.
quotation.source: Mulder in X-FILES #1

quotation.p: "Hey, Mulder... how was therapy?"
"Pretty good. Today I remembered getting my first library card. Unfortunately, the name on it was Hans Holzer."
quotation.source: Scully and Mulder reassemble their memories in X-FILES #2

quotation.p: "Ah, you remember our names, Mulder. Recovering?"
"Still some gaps, Byers. The phrase 'Rosebud' rings a bell, but I can't place it."
quotation.source: Mulder and Byers, in X-FILES #3

quotation.p: "You know, when we heard you'd debunked Neola, we were afraid you'd gone over to the other side."
"Nah -- the hours stink but the pay's good."
quotation.source: Frohike and Mulder, in X-FILES #3

quotation.p: "Congratulations. You're finally meeting one of those magical creatures you've spent so much time looking for. "
"Funny... you don't look like a leprechaun, Lieutenant Colonel Dunne."
quotation.source: Dunne and Mulder in X-FILES #3

quotation.p: "Mulder... this disk wouldn't contain Pentagon access codes, would it?"
"Actually it's Doom II. You know how the Bureau frowns on computer games."
quotation.source: Scully and Mulder in X-FILES #3

quotation.p: Now that you're dead, Mulder and Scully and Drake, as dead as the trees in December, maybe you can understand what it is that I am.
quotation.source: The narrator, in X-FILES #7

quotation.p: Our friend believes that, unlike us working stiffs, he lives backwards and forwards in time.
quotation.source: Mulder, in X-FILES #7

quotation.p: And all the while, the computers dreamed of zeroes and ones -- unable to imagine a two.
quotation.source: The narrator, in X-FILES #7

quotation.p: "Who are you?"
"Oh, pardon me ... Zachary T. Paleozogt, at your service. But you can call me Zot!"
quotation.source: Jenny and Zot, in ZOT! #1

quotation.p: Welcome, one and all, to the far-flung future of -- 1965!
quotation.source: Zot, in ZOT! #1

quotation.p: "Aww, c'mon! Where's your sense of fun?"
"I'm the standard model, Zachary. 'Fun' was optional."
quotation.source: Zot and Peabody, in ZOT! #1

quotation.p: Guards! Guards! Stop this madman! He's turning everyone into monkeys!
quotation.source: A sudden intrusion, in ZOT! #1

quotation.p: "My, how you've grown!"
"C'mon, it's only been a week and a half!"
quotation.source: Uncle Max and Zot, in ZOT! #2

quotation.p: "How about you -- what're you up to?"
"Issue #3."
quotation.source: Vic and Zot, in ZOT! #3

quotation.p: Y'see, I figure I've got two choices at my stage. I can try to make my world grow bigger, or I can let it get smaller -- and if I don't do the one then the other's gonna happen in time...
quotation.source: Uncle Max, in ZOT! #3

quotation.p: I'm sorry I became abusive just now ... calling you worms... I was just speaking relatively, you understand.
quotation.source: Dekko, in ZOT! #3

quotation.p: "Ah, the stench of evil is about this place!"
"Actually, I think that's air-freshener."
quotation.source: Prince Drufus and Vic, in ZOT! #4
